text: Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth.

When a grizzly bear catches a salmon, she’ll
first peel off and gobble up the skin, then
nom the brain.

But then, she’s likely to abandon the rest
of the fish - several kilograms worth - and
go back to the river to catch another.

On average, bears abandon about half of their
yearly haul.
But why?

I mean, catching fish can be a real bear;
it doesn’t seem to make sense to waste all
that time and effort.

But the bear is acting much more logically
than you might think.

Because the process of acquiring food isn't
just about getting it into your paws - it's

also about getting it from your paws to your
jaws...and eventually your belly.

And sure, that’s easy for some animals and
some foods; but for others, the processing

is just as hard - or harder - than getting
a paw on it in the first place, or beak or
fang.

For a bear in salmon season, fish is easy
to come by; dismantling that fish is what
takes the real time and energy.

Some parts of a salmon are more worthwhile
than others.

The fattiest bits of the fish - the skin,
the brain, and the eggs - are the most calorie
rich and easiest to access.

The rest of the fish's flesh - which is much
leaner and not nearly as rewarding - is tucked

amidst dangerously sharp broken bones which
are really hard to pick apart.

And for a bear, time is money, or really,
salmoney; time spent processing food is time

not spent catching more food, baby-making,
or keeping an eye out for foes.

The same is true for critters like spotted
hyenas, gray wolves, orcas, midges, spiders,

and foxes, whose prey also takes time to dismantle;
when there’s plenty of prey to be had, these

animals will often kill more prey than they
can eat, consuming the best bits and leaving
the rest bear-ly touched.

Meanwhile, a pelican - which spends far more
time searching for fish than eating them - will
eat pretty much everything it can catch.

Generally, the more time a critter has to
spend eating its prey, the more often it should

abandon what it has already caught and try
for something better.

Of course, animals don’t actually do complex
math to figure out what’s worthwhile.

These decisions are generally driven by instincts
honed over millions of years of natural selection,

supplemented by their past experiences and
info they’ve gained from others.

And even when a bear decides that a salmon
in the paw isn’t worth two in the stream,
that fish doesn’t actually go to waste.

The discarded meat gets picked over by other
animals, and whatever’s left over is decomposed

by even smaller critters, creating a nutrient-rich
landscape that can bear even more bears.

I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but humans
– even well intentioned ones – are often
wasteful in ways that benefit no one.

That’s why I like this video’s sponsor,
Wren.

I took a 2 minute quiz about my habits and
lifestyle on Wren’s website, and it generated

a personalized report estimating how much
carbon my activities release into the atmosphere

- and how quickly the Earth would warm if
everyone in the world lived like I do.

But Wren not only allows me to bear some responsibility
by suggesting how to reduce my individual

carbon footprint, it also allows me to offset
the carbon that I do release by making a monthly

contribution towards projects like turning
wildfire-burned trees into natural crop fertilizer
or forest protection.

And for each of the first 100 of you who sign
up using the link in the description, Wren

will fund an extra 5 acres of rainforest protection
per person.
Thanks Wren!
